Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Enhance the Resilience of Water Infrastructure in Mid-sized Cities Adjacent to Energy Industry

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1759542 (Lou)/1760673 (Reible). At the heart of U.S. energy and chemical processing industry, Hurricane Harvey caused multiple chemical spills/explosions, flooding of superfund sites, and even the flooding of a primary pump station, which draws river water to a drinking water treatment plant (WTP). If the source water is contaminated by hazardous chemicals released from multiple sources, compounded by the failure of a WTP, public health, and also productivity of the local industry will be severely threatened. This study will address drinking water safety issues under threats of the release of hazardous chemicals during major natural disasters, and identify strategies to improve infrastructure resilience in mid-sized cities.

This research will obtain extremely valuable data relating to the drinking water quality and the release to transport of hazardous chemicals caused by Harvey. The investigation will provide answers to the following critical questions: 1) What kind of hazardous chemicals in an energy production region have the highest risk to be released and contaminate source water under major natural disasters? 2) What are their distribution, fate and transport patterns from the source point to WTP intake spots? 3) What strategies should be taken to enhance the resilience of the drinking water system in mid-sized coastal cities adjacent to energy industry? The research results will provide communities a better understanding of the risks and how to manage them. The contingency plan can be applied to small and mid-sized cities, which often have limited resources and few alternatives. The strategies identified will enhance the integrity of urban infrastructure, as well as the normal production of industrial activities.

The project aims at investigating the water supply safety issues under threats of the release of hazardous chemicals during major natural disasters, and identify strategies to improve the infrastructure resilience in mid-sized cities adjacent to the energy industry.

Hurricane Harvey led to record rainfalls in southeast Texas between August 25 through August 30, 2017.  This led to significant flooding and a high risk of hazardous chemical releases into surface waters. The primary pump station, which draws source water from the Neches River to the Beaumont DWTP, was heavily flooded. As a result, approximately 120,000 residents suffered a tap water outage from August 31 to September 9, 2017. A temporary pump station was set up at the upstream end of Brakes Bayou, close to Beaumont Water Treatment Plant, and was operated from September 1st to 6th. The lower reaches of Brakes Bayou are bounded to the west by a Superfund site containing substantial PAHs contamination and an island (CBI) to the east with significant industrial activity.

The team collected surface water samples, rive bank soil samples and drinking water samples starting from September 3, 2017. The organic and inorganic contaminants in the samples were analyzed. Sources with high risks were identified. The fate and transport processes of the major contaminants were studies.

 High concentration of Trihalomethanes (THMs, EPA recommendation: 80 ppb; highest observed: 220 ppb) and Total Organic Carbons (TOCs, EPA recommendation: 2ppm; highest observed: 3.6 ppm) were observed in many tap water samples collected at different locations in Beaumont in September 2017. The typical disinfectant in the Beaumont Water Treatment Plant is chloramine. During Hurricane Harvey, chlorine gas was used to enhance the disinfection, in turn elevated levels of THMs were observed. It was switched back to chloramine after the hurricane. Most high concentrations of THMs were observed during the period that the city gave water-boil notice.

 Elevated concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) were observed in the surface water samples collected from Brakes Bayou?s section adjacent to a superfund site and the temporary water intake. The large volumes of water associated with Harvey likely led to substantial dilution of any contaminants although only limited sampling could be conducted before that time during the peak of the flooding. The flooding associated with Harvey may also have led to exposure of contaminant sources that then led to storm water releases during lesser storms.  If the drinking water intake had continued to operate from the temporary location, the later storm could have led to significantly elevated PAHs in the drinking water intake, even though the temporary pump station was built upstream of the superfund site.

 The team screened potential treatment techniques that could be implemented at a centralized water treatment plant to address potential PAHs contaminants.  Extensive experiments were conducted to study two promising PAHs removal methods: (a). activated carbon (AC) absorption and (b). advanced oxidation using potassium permanganate (KMnO4, or PM)/ sodium bisulfite (NaHSO3, or BS). The impacts of humic substances on PAHs removal methods were compared. The results give valuable guidance to the design and operation of water treatment processes for the removal of PAHs from water.

For the first time, this research identified an infrastructure vulnerability caused by the nexus of drinking water supply, hurricane and hazardous waste management. Even though the energy and chemical plants along the coastal area have accumulated numerous experiences to protect against the hurricanes, the scale of Harvey far exceeded the capacity of plants? and regions? common emergency management practices. Lack of redundancy, improper storage/management of hazardous wastes are the key issues caused the failure of the water infrastructure. Especially, the hazardous wastes close to the key waterway should be well managed. The team developed a contingency plan and submitted to local authorities.
